facts.text: Police filed a report before the Chief Presidency Magistrate at Calcutta in February, 1958 charging ten accused persons including the appellant of offenses under s. 120-B read with s. 409 and s. 477, Indian Penal Code.

By an order of the State Government dated June 1, 1959, notified in the official Gazette, the said case was assigned to the Calcutta Additional Special Court under s. 4(2) of the West Bengal Criminal Law Amendment (Special Courts) Act, 1949.

On September 26, 1959, the Investigating Officer of the Enforcement Branch, Calcutta, filed a petition before the Special judge praying that the judge might be pleased to take cognizance of the case which had been allotted to him and issue process against the several accused.
On the same day September 26, 1959, the Additional Special judge took cognizance of the offenses and issued notices to the accused persons fixing a date for their appearance.

On receipt of this notice the appellant made an application before the Special judge stating that the initiation of the proceedings the petition of the Investigating Branch, Calcutta, was not proper and legal.
The Additional Special judge rejected that petition.

The appellant then moved the High Court of Calcutta in revision, Criminal Revision No. 1557 of 1959, urging that the Special judge could not take cognizance of the offence on the complaint of the police officer and had therefore no jurisdiction to proceed with the trial.

In two earlier decisions of the Calcutta High Court the view had been held that a Special judge did not acquire jurisdiction merely on allotment under s. 4(2), but needed to comply with s. 190(1) CrPC otherwise than on police report.

The Division Bench referred the matter to Full Bench: Does the Special Judge need a petition of complaint for taking cognizance or does he take cognizance when receiving Government notification and record, applying mind?
Full Bench by majority: Special Court takes cognizance when on receiving Government Notification and records, applies mind and takes steps. Earlier decisions incorrect.
West Bengal Legislature enacted Act XXIV of 1960 amending s.5(1) to allow cognizance in manner of s.190(1)(a) and (b) CrPC.
Full Bench held amendment does not invalidate prior proceedings; governed by pre-amendment Act.
Revision petition dismissed by Calcutta High Court on June 8, 1961.
Appellant comes to Supreme Court by special leave.

legal_issues.text: Proper construction of ss. 4 and 5 of the West Bengal Criminal Law Amendment (Special Courts) Act, 1949: Does Special Court need to comply with s.190(1) CrPC to take cognizance, or is allotment under s.4(2) sufficient?
Effect of 1960 amendment to s.5(1) on pending proceedings.

petitioner_arguments.text: Special Judge could not take cognizance on police complaint; must comply with s.190(1) CrPC otherwise than on police report. Allotment under s.4(2) not equivalent to committal; cognizance distinct from jurisdiction to trial.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.190(1) CrPC; s.5(1) WB Act 1949; Bhajahari Mondal v. State of WB

petitioner_arguments.text: 1960 Amending Act declaratory, accepting need for s.190 compliance from original enactment.

respondent_arguments.text: Jurisdiction arises from notification under s.4(2); no need for s.190 CrPC compliance as Special Court not a Magistrate under s.190.

court_reasoning.text: Special Court not within Magistrates under s.190(1) CrPC; nor Sessions Court requiring committal u/s 193. Jurisdiction from allotment u/s 4(2), substitute for committal. Cognizance when judge applies mind to facts upon receiving records and notification.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Word 'cognizance' means judicial notice; no statutory material required beyond allotment.

court_reasoning.text: s.5(1) 'otherwise than on police report' excludes s.251A procedure, not requiring s.190(b).
court_reasoning.key_observation: No general jurisprudence requires additional material.

court_reasoning.text: 1960 amendment effects change, not declaratory; does not invalidate prior valid proceedings.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No retrospective effect or invalidation provision.

court_reasoning.text: Explains Bhajahari Mondal: Jurisdiction from notification; cognizance upon applying mind, not requiring s.190 material.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.529 CrPC inapplicable to Special Judge.

holdings.text: Special Court vested with jurisdiction upon State Govt allotment u/s 4(2); takes cognizance by applying mind to case facts upon receiving notification and records; no need for s.190 CrPC compliance.
1960 amendment not declaratory or invalidating prior proceedings; Special Court jurisdiction governed by pre-amendment Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bhajahari Mondal v. The State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Jurisdiction from s.4(2) notification; cognizance upon receipt of record and applying mind, not requiring s.190 material
Definition of cognizance as point when Magistrate takes judicial notice of offence

precedents_cited.case_name: R. R. Chari v. State of Uttar Pradesh

precedents_cited.relevance: Taking cognizance occurs as soon as Magistrate applies mind to suspected offence

precedents_cited.case_name: Two earlier Calcutta High Court decisions
precedents_cited.relevance: Held need for s.190 compliance; overruled by Full Bench and affirmed

statutes_cited.name: West Bengal Criminal Law Amendment (Special Courts) Act, 1949 (W.B. XXI of 1949)
statutes_cited.relevance: Constitutes Special Courts for speedy trial of scheduled offences; allotment vests jurisdiction; procedure follows warrant cases not on police report

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: s.190 inapplicable to Special Court; no committal needed; s.251A excluded; s.529 inapplicable

statutes_cited.name: West Bengal Criminal Law Amendment (Special Courts) Amending Act, 1960 (Act XXIV of 1960)
statutes_cited.relevance: Allows cognizance per s.190(1)(a),(b) CrPC; procedural, applies prospectively without invalidating prior acts

outcome.summary: The appeal is dismissed. The Supreme Court upholds the Full Bench decision of Calcutta High Court that the Special Judge validly took cognizance upon allotment under s.4(2) and applying mind to records, without needing s.190 CrPC compliance under pre-amendment law; 1960 amendment does not affect prior proceedings.

key_quotes.text: The word cognizance has no esoteric or mystic significance in criminal law or procedure. It merely means become aware of and when used with reference to a Court or judge, to take notice of judicially.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines 'cognizance' central to resolving jurisdiction issue

key_quotes.text: As soon as a special judge receives the orders of allotment of the case passed by the State Government it becomes vested with jurisdiction to try the case and when it receives the record from the Government it can apply its mind and issue notice to the accused.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: States when Special Court acquires jurisdiction and takes cognizance
